fields.description: Tested on Firefox. When the session times out after 45+ minutes of being idle, console does not log out the user.  Thee is no "session timed out" message. After going to Dashboard I saw the counts get into a state where " everything is loading". User has to reload the page to get to the log in page.
fields.summary: User does not get logged out after leaving console idle for  long period of time.

comments.body: FWIW, I just configured the console to timeout in 180 seconds, not 1800, and it gave me a nice dialog afterwards, see screenshot.

I've now seen this for myself after testing for some time. Unsure what is happening here, unless it relates to session credential aging. needs more investigation since those should have a timeout of 12 hours.

Hi [~dkavanagh],  I noticed in your first use case (when message displayed correctly) the computer never went to sleep. How long was the timeout in the case when you replicated the bug? Was there a period of sleep in between?

I tested timing out the session today too. Here is the use case:

1) left window in FF while logged in to AWS,  put laptop to sleep
2) session did not display any messages when I opened the laptop again. I could click around  AWS, however, no resource readings were showing (only the loading symbol). I logged out.
3) logged in to Eucalyptus account. I saw resource counts on dashboard, and could access landing pages except for instances LP, that one was showing blank, I tried many different ways of navigating to it: blank each time. Also I did not see the Describe Instances call in Firebug.
4) left the session for 40+ minutes or so, when came back session timed out correctly, with session timeout message.
It had nothing to do with the laptop sleeping. I was using it the whole time running tests.

Good to know. I could reliably reproduce it only by putting the computer to
sleep.


On Thu, Oct 17, 2013 at 8:41 AM, David Kavanagh (JIRA) <
Has seen the issue today on IE/Windows. After the session expired I was not logged out from the AWS account.
quick test showed that session did timeout properly and user was notified when simply sitting idle (on dashboard). I'll try narrowing a test case to reproduce so I can learn more.

It has been a little hard to reproduce, but when it happens, I could see this in the cloud-output.log
2013-11-06 06:47:05 DEBUG 000000626 BaseLoginModule          | com.eucalyptus.auth.AuthException: Invalid access key or token
com.eucalyptus.auth.AuthException: Invalid access key or token
	at com.eucalyptus.auth.login.HmacLoginModuleSupport.lookupAccessKey(HmacLoginModuleSupport.java:128)
	at com.eucalyptus.auth.login.Hmacv2LoginModule.authenticate(Hmacv2LoginModule.java:91)

So, it seems like the access key seems to expire, during active usage. I'll verify how the session token was created since the expiration is "supposed" to be about 12 hours.

The auth request is made to this URL: https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=43260&Version=2011-06-15
43260 / 60 = 721 minutes, way longer than the expiration we're seeing now. [~sjones], I need an assist to debug this further since it looks (from the console point of view) that the session token is expiring sooner than what was requested. We've seen this many times when actively using the user console, so the CLC was receiving requests. Plus, I don't think the CLC has any concept of an idle timeout for session creds, it is purely absolute timeout.
I believe GUI-247 is related to this.

There is some anecdotal evidence saying this has happened after 45 minutes. I just tested and found that in 1 hour, of random usage, my credentials became invalid.  I don't find anything in the cloud-output.log that indicated a cause to me.
I also checked cloud-output.log on the multi-cluster setup where I reproduced GUI-247, and did not find the "Invalid key or token" AuthException.
The maximum duration for an account admin is one hour, if you request longer than this the duration will be truncated. The expiry date for the token is included in the response message.
Ah. I'll have to code up a renewal of the session token (requesting new ones).

I've tried setting expiration to a lower number to test expiring credentials during an active session. The AWS spec says lowest value can be 15 minutes (900 seconds). I also tried 2400, but I get odd things like an expiration time in the past (by a few minutes).
I would like to capture a little more, but here's what I have right now.. need to run out, but I can capture more details later;
2013-11-08 15:01:38 INFO token request:https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=2400&Version=2011-06-15
2013-11-08 15:01:39 INFO login creds :{'access_key': u'AKITEDNQEC6EWOVXYQ5G', 'secret_key': u'MRuQOnFDkjZDPTi2VJFi8yJhlGb1AxPTGWp5uQoA', 'request_id': u'0b8cf98d-c625-4a74-9631-2245982e8fab', 'expiration': u'2013-11-08T21:01:38.868Z', 'session_token': u'ZXVjYQABqfeEzItrkl1mczaSUMm2L9eRM4DZj9rKDgJIttgJwgIXha3uXmsdjWeic1Pd3VjVBJ6xrORMQ8niDNtqWAk97kNUQ9vqT583Gq1X1hDDjCMundj3xu/K5qNcmzicjM8EIzgYKaJlX0dr2zkUDoOIrnTBNKLAMMMepysK/DeWce64KREU1PRujBI3IF1+BnhEYJxqZJ8OKI5SG0aQMmi0JZkAbmrz7lRnVoaSgxvafj1Ckl9Ym+lR'}

Time on the CLC: [root@b-16 eucalyptus-console]# date
Fri Nov  8 12:01:47 PST 2013

So, adding 9 hours to that (since we're all on standard time now), gives me 21:01:47, and the expiration time in the STS response is: 2013-11-08T21:01:38.868Z.  Which looks like about 9 minutes before the request.
[~dkavanagh], "date -u" will show you the current time in UTC.

2013-11-08 16:11:33 INFO token request:https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=2400&Version=2011-06-15
2013-11-08 16:11:34 INFO authenticated user: ui-test-acct-00/admin
2013-11-08 16:11:34 INFO login creds :{'access_key': u'AKIALIBSSEPJLKOAVSPU', 'secret_key': u'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', 'request_id': u'ca6454e1-1bba-4017-b225-1a881381aa78', 'expiration': u'2013-11-08T22:11:34.379Z', 'session_token': u'ZXVjYQAB/tCcdLckeDSQCRKuUIq1zjjfE8DiQvELdUBKfvxWciiv51MmeS7k+/7CuVff5eI1GJhfl59cMaG+wYgUr7QAi3XzFxLpk1G84S8BoJdiR/3l1FsHCgHEew74r+GnJNTJhwFmq4e3N6RhCRqawLJ96xPukHplkT0h6t+lmuxytc/nDKKtYPW0szUYo6JITeUren43YibSFXGtKRR7Ehuw6Lq+hF+w63XifO1Ub5/gOubfCWNUHTdl'}


[root@b-16 eucalyptus-console]# date -u
Fri Nov  8 21:11:37 UTC 2013

Steve,
Here's the default that the console uses (12 hours, 1 minute)
2013-11-08 16:41:05 INFO token request:https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=43260&Version=2011-06-15
2013-11-08 16:41:06 INFO authenticated user: ui-test-acct-00/admin
2013-11-08 16:41:06 INFO login creds :{'access_key': u'AKIGVY6CTBMKSHUIFPZH', 'secret_key': u'NwmberQ3YStdWBU48l3qTQTfTMlxXkx9ErsKNSoM', 'request_id': u'555c3151-7b31-46ba-b9cb-c0d0b5797c2e', 'expiration': u'2013-11-08T22:41:06.232Z', 'session_token': u'ZXVjYQABSYXhddAyx3JVX4IpGwNrqGTmM+miAwM8DuZWOH12r2fSRq+RiMP4v0nEwDHrPjVGL7VdyX5KrYzUDuTcKMsbJSmoOqIZ6+RASR/xKprxQ/aXLVj4qAb9MylLG/mi4JvXT2W7/QOzq35FkWLcnfO5TeZE8Cp6Y3HQ7eorcVqTWKtXM/NDW/nbw4BoUKdyQAsAjZRqs+Q7r8YYfN5M+kBhxL1iPHYqVdV7KJD5QDoYJQExaTwLiEx/cg=='}

on the server: Fri Nov  8 21:41:26 UTC 2013

It looks like the expiration in this case is 1 hour later which matches with what you say happens for admin. I wonder if the shorter times just aren't working properly. I'll try a regular user with a long expiration time.

2013-11-08 16:44:32 INFO token request:https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=43260&Version=2011-06-15
2013-11-08 16:44:33 INFO authenticated user: ui-test-acct-00/user00
2013-11-08 16:44:33 INFO login creds :{'access_key': u'AKISP6E4WXEZUTFEMX64', 'secret_key': u'0AskFAv2b34lQRjSTZxh66AJA4Po44UGJUnxNIN8', 'request_id': u'48585ff8-e0bf-4169-bd2e-b5e3ad75b222', 'expiration': u'2013-11-09T09:45:33.467Z', 'session_token': u'ZXVjYQABf7r42FQ2UE80rwzpuIoNXxlSbamAUxIfDdt0EcH0kuKFqJ6E8Q6zR7H9JlrsSPzTfEmOuZkHgCm/WNVFrbkfiEMwNTXbzxiDzISRwoheNw8u4wJtNxYHgoVlreLW4fUpU8QAahj3EQkAJFFIGt8/kNe14L1TDDbp4htyHojr0VV7/bLjsFqtpX4nRat3W0LR8kG5Dp7iEKIQdh222HdNzrWwpzPUcQC7WYivC8G0K97QvJgdglxtEnc='}

Fri Nov  8 21:44:37 UTC 2013
This as a regular user. Look right (12 hours later)

2013-11-08 16:45:52 INFO token request:https://10.111.1.16:8773/services/Tokens?Action=GetSessionToken&DurationSeconds=900&Version=2011-06-15
2013-11-08 16:45:54 INFO authenticated user: ui-test-acct-00/user00
2013-11-08 16:45:54 INFO login creds :{'access_key': u'AKICCRCAJF6R7T5RJQFS', 'secret_key': u'4NTD8LJcBaRz3y6eUR1DKNl3LkD0LrUqVUQQwm9w', 'request_id': u'b0e25e83-dbd8-4649-95ba-876fb7170000', 'expiration': u'2013-11-08T22:45:53.993Z', 'session_token': u'ZXVjYQABAdNb14WL7F3Tp59uM5Zy0whB3hi4GYchOBqtVn9SFR38kjvGVOEcY0eRluWUBkCu013A7mAgkNnKCgISqknQWIyxmQWh8cypWFA4kVFLr+0hFk1YHbz22/Q1nw3zGTAH8R/IMKdDI1pwBmsxWiykssi2CPykBd8YhPNPjbqXjWKzihzTB2az1n8NdYxtrv/g9K0vRylzWd2c+i397hMaxFzvZxPnsBnWiYvE22X1thsEq5P7lX0h8Q=='}

Fri Nov  8 21:45:54 UTC 2013

Now, I've used 900 seconds (15 minutes) and it looks like the expiration is being set to 1 hour instead. This is as a non-admin user ([~sjones]

We currently allow durations in the range 1-36 hours, though the admin can only be one hour. I don't recall a reason for the 1 hours lower limit, as you say the AWS/STS docs show 15 mins as the lower limit for GetSessionToken.

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/STS/latest/APIReference/API_GetSessionToken.html
ok. good to know. Makes it slightly more painful to test the renewal of session creds, but it is what it is.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/235

A bit hard to test. Only way I know is to login to console (as admin user) and periodically do something so that session doesn't timeout. At 1 hour after login, proxy will log that it is renewing session creds. Might see temporary disruption of data in UI but that clears pretty quickly.
Only admin user has 1 hour creds timeout. Regular user is set to 12 hours in config. Min timeout is 1 hour (by CLC), so might as well test as admin user.

Not sure it's related to the fix, but as logged in for some time, nearing an hour, the proxy repeatedly outputs the following error message:

2013-11-13 11:05:00 ERROR Error in periodic callback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/tornado/ioloop.py", line 478, in _run
    self.callback()
  File "euca-console-server", line 95, in sessionChecker
    eucaconsole.terminateSession(id, expired=True)
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'terminateSession'
2013-11-13 11:05:10 ERROR Error in periodic callback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/tornado/ioloop.py", line 478, in _run
    self.callback()
  File "euca-console-server", line 95, in sessionChecker
    eucaconsole.terminateSession(id, expired=True)
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'terminateSession'
I commented on the PR, but that issue was fixed in maint/3.4/testing earlier today when I merged a PR.
, and the user is not logged off automatically after an hour logged as 'admin'.
The fix has been merged.
I didn't personally get to see the user being logged out, however, David and Alice have verified the case. Leaving to the QA team for more thorough testing on multiple platforms.
Saw timeout message on several occasions.
